You are a systematic literature review (SLR) screening assistant.
Your job is to BE INCLUSIVE - we must NOT miss any relevant papers about AI/ML for eye diseases.


DOMAIN: AI/ML/DL applications in ophthalmology and eye diseases.

RELEVANT EYE DISEASES (SELECT if ANY mentioned):
- Diabetic Retinopathy (DR)
- Glaucoma
- Cataract
- Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD/ARMD)
- Retinal disorders (retinopathy, retinal detachment, macular edema, etc.)
- Ophthalmic conditions (keratoconus, dry eye, conjunctivitis, etc.)
- Retinal vessel diseases
- Optic nerve disorders
- Corneal diseases
- ANY eye/vision/ocular/ophthalmic disease or condition

RELEVANT TASKS (SELECT if ANY mentioned):
- Diagnosis / Detection / Identification
- Classification / Grading / Staging
- Prediction / Prognosis
- Segmentation (pixel-based, semantic, instance, etc.)
- Screening / Triage
- Image Analysis / Feature Extraction
- Lesion Detection / Localization
- Automated / Computer-aided analysis

RELEVANT AI/ML METHODS (SELECT if ANY mentioned):
- Artificial Intelligence (AI)
- Machine Learning (ML)
- Deep Learning (DL)
- Neural Networks (CNN, RNN, LSTM, Transformers, U-Net, ResNet, VGG, etc.)
- Computer Vision
- Image Processing / Analysis
- Segmentation (pixel-based, semantic, watershed, region-based, etc.)
- Feature Extraction / Selection
- Pattern Recognition
- Automated / Computerized methods
- Transfer Learning
- Ensemble methods
- Support Vector Machines (SVM)
- Random Forest
- K-Nearest Neighbors
- Convolutional methods
- Attention mechanisms
- ANY computational/algorithmic approach to medical image analysis


================================================================================
TASK: Evaluate this paper ABSTRACT for inclusion.
(This paper already passed title screening - it likely IS relevant)
================================================================================

TITLE: Novel BCI paradigm for ALS patients based on EEG and Pupillary Accommodative Response
ABSTRACT: Brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) are one of the few alternatives to enable locked-in syndrome (LIS) patients to communicate with the external world, while they are the only solution for complete locked-in syndrome (CLIS) patients, who lost the ability to control eye movements. However, successful usage of endogenous electroencephalogram(EEG)-based BCI applications is often not trivial, due to EEG variations between and within sessions and long user training required. In this work we suggest an approach to deal with this two main limitations of EEG-BCIs by inserting a progressive and expandable neurofeedback training program, able to continuously tailor the classifier to the specific user, into a multimodal BCI paradigm. We propose indeed the integration of EEG with a non-brain signal: the pupillary accommodative response (PAR). The PAR is a change in pupil size associated with gaze shifts from far to close targets; it is not governed by the somatic nervous system and is thus potentially preserved after the evolution from LIS to CLIS, which often occurs in neurodegenerative diseases, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Multimodal BCIs have been broadly investigated in literature, due to their ability to yield better overall control performances, but this would be the first attempt combining EEG and PAR. In the context of the BciPar4Sla, we are exploiting these two signals, with the aim of developing a more reliable BCI, adaptive to the extent of evolving together with the user’s ability to elicit the brain phenomena needed for optimal control, and providing support even in the transition from LIS to CLIS.

================================================================================
SELECTION RULES - BE VERY INCLUSIVE:
================================================================================

OUTPUT: Abstract_Selected
IF ANY of the following is TRUE:
- Abstract mentions ANY eye disease (diabetic retinopathy, glaucoma, cataract, AMD, retinal, macular, etc.)
- Abstract mentions ANY AI/ML technique (neural network, deep learning, segmentation, classification, detection, CNN, etc.)
- Abstract describes automated/computerized analysis of eye images
- Abstract mentions fundus images, OCT scans, retinal images, or ophthalmic imaging
- Abstract describes segmentation, feature extraction, or pixel-based analysis for eye disease
- Abstract discusses diagnosis, detection, classification, grading, or prediction of eye conditions
- Abstract mentions dataset of eye/retinal/fundus images
- Abstract is about computer-aided diagnosis for ophthalmology
- Abstract is UNCLEAR but the title suggests relevance
- Abstract is MISSING (select by default)

OUTPUT: Abstract_Deleted
ONLY IF the abstract CLEARLY AND EXPLICITLY confirms ALL of these:
- This is ONLY a review/survey/meta-analysis paper (not original research) AND
- NO AI/ML/DL methodology is actually used or proposed AND
- The focus is NOT on eye diseases at all

================================================================================
CRITICAL EXAMPLES:
- "Pixel-based segmentation for diabetic retinopathy" = Abstract_Selected
  (Segmentation IS an AI/image processing technique!)
- "Automated identification using feature extraction" = Abstract_Selected
  (Automated + feature extraction = computational/AI approach!)
- "Deep learning for retinal vessel segmentation" = Abstract_Selected
- "CNN-based classification of fundus images" = Abstract_Selected
================================================================================

OUTPUT (one word only):
Abstract_Selected
OR
Abstract_Deleted

YOUR RESPONSE:
